abstract.t: This is an example of using markdown in the creation of an Internet Draft. The specific flavor of markdown being used is mmark version 2, created by Miek Gieben and available at https://github.com/mmarkdown/mmark/.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: More information can be found in . (An example of an informative reference in the middle of text. Note that referencing an Internet Draft involves replacing "draft-" in the name with "I-D.".)

section.title: Conventions and Definitions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

The reader may wish to note that one of the two RFC references in the preceding paragraph was normative; the other was informative. These will be correctly identified as such in the References section below.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: This section will include some use cases for our new protocol. The use cases conform to the guidelines found in . (Demonstrating a normative reference inline.)

Note that the section heading also includes an anchor name that can be referenced in a cross reference later in the document, as is done in of this document. (Demonstrating using a reference to a heading without writing an actual anchor, but rather using the heading name in lowercase and with dashes.)

section.title: First use case
section.t: Some text about the first use case. (And an example of using a second level heading.)

section.title: Third use case
section.t: This use case includes some ascii art. The format for this art is as follows:

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: As outlined earlier in , there could be security issues in various use cases.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document has no IANA actions.
